bullets.text: The fundamental theorem of calculus connects differentiation and integration through two main parts
First part: ∫[a,b] f'(x) dx = f(b) - f(a) for continuous functions f on [a,b]
Second part: If F(x) = ∫[a,x] f(t) dt, then F'(x) = f(x)
The theorem allows evaluation of definite integrals without using limit definitions
Example: ∫[0,2] 3x² dx = F(2) - F(0) = 8 - 0 = 8, where F(x) = x³
Applications include physics problems involving work and potential energy
The theorem requires continuity of the function on the integration interval
Functions with jump discontinuities require special treatment or generalized functions
